awd_titl_txt: Cortical Representations for Value-Based Decision Making
awd_abstract_narration:
Making good decisions -- in domains such as diet, finances, educational attainment, and public policy -- requires evaluating and comparing options that may be complex and multifaceted. Previous brain imaging research has shown that a frontal region called the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC) has an important role in producing subjective value estimates for individual options during decision making. Activity in this region varies with the subjective value of the options under consideration. However, vmPFC also participates in many other cognitive functions, and its internal functional organization is not yet understood in detail. In particular, it is not yet known whether valuation signals originate from the same parts of vmPFC that have been implicated in processes such as memory, planning, and self-referential thinking. The present research will compare the patterns of vmPFC activity associated with valuation and non-valuation processes in individual brains. The results will help develop improved methods for measuring the engagement of specific cognitive processes from brain imaging data. Because vmPFC is thought to encode variables akin to economic utility, this work will contribute to the growing interdisciplinary dialogue between neuroscience and economics. The project will enhance the usefulness of neuroscience methods for understanding economic decision making and thereby contribute to the advancement of societally relevant economic goals. The interdisciplinary nature of the project will create rich educational opportunities for students and trainees involved in conducting the research. 

The project will use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to test whether valuation effects in vmPFC can be topographically segregated from default-mode-network (DMN) effects when examined at the level of the single individual. The project involves a collaboration between researchers with expertise in neuroeconomics and vision science, as a means to import high-fidelity data analysis techniques from visual neuroscience to studies of decision making. Valuation tasks will be interleaved with manipulations of DMN deactivation in a test-retest protocol. Valuation and DMN effects have been shown to be diffusely co-localized within vmPFC in existing meta-analyses, but it is unknown whether they originate from the same or different cortical parcels in individuals. A test-retest design will allow comparisons of activation patterns within and across tasks. One possible outcome is that valuation and DMN effects may turn out to be associated with segregable patterns of cortical engagement. Such a finding would drive the development of sensitive and specific methods for reading out valuation-related activity, and would provide new tools for studying how the brain's valuation system is modulated by learning, context, and the engagement of control processes. An alternative outcome is that valuation and DMN effects may exhibit high topographic correspondence. This outcome would motivate new theoretical models of shared neural operations between these seemingly disparate cognitive processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Background
Human ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC) is engaged during higher-order cognitive activities such as value-based decision making. Our understanding of the role of vmPFC in cognition has been constrained by two factors: first, vmPFC is implicated in a large array of heterogeneous cognitive functions; second, the anatomy and functional topography of vmPFC vary substantially from one person to another, limiting the precision with which we can compare findings from previous studies of individual cognitive domains.

This project examined whether valuation-related effects in vmPFC emerge from the same cortical parcels that are part of the "default network," a distributed brain system implicated in memory, episodic thought, and self-referential cognition. Insofar as valuation effects topographically align with the default network in individual brains, this would motivate integrative theories of how a core cortical system participates in disparate cognitive processes. Conversely, insofar as valuation effects can be segregated from the default network, this would increase the specificity with which valuation-related activity could be identified in neuroimaging data and would provide precise analysis targets for future studies of decision processes.

Outcomes
We collected a test-retest fMRI data set in which individual participants performed interleaved runs of a working memory task, a monetary wagering task, and resting visual fixation. Data acquisition and processing protocols were designed to maximize signal and spatial fidelity in vmPFC while minimizing and compensating for susceptibility-related distortion/dropout and physiological artifact. Each participant performed the full set of interleaved runs twice on separate days a week apart, yielding independent data sets for analyses in each individual's native neuroanatomical space.

Analyses of task-related effects provided evidence of shared topographic structure between valuation effects and the default network. The cortical topography of each participant's default network was estimated on the basis of both resting-state functional correlations and task-evoked effects from the working memory task. Analyses of the monetary wagering task estimated two types of valuation-related effects: brain responses to the expected value before the decision was made and brain responses to reward prediction error after the outcome was delivered. As expected, vmPFC exhibited valuation effects and was part of the default network, and patterns of effects in vmPFC were more similar within-person (across independent sessions) than across people. Comparing the effects from the two tasks showed that valuation effects were more similar to the default network within-person than across people, indicative of shared individual-level structure between the two domains.

We applied network-theoretic clustering methods to subdivide vmPFC and related brain areas into functionally coherent subnetworks. The resulting subnetworks were consistent across sessions and across tasks for a given individual but differed across individuals, implying that a stable, participant-unique network structure was present regardless of task context. Valuation effects were present in the subnetwork that most closely corresponded to the default network.

Broader impacts
The project supported the training of graduate and undergraduate students, two of whom have completed their degrees and secured scientific positions for the next stage of their training. The data set collected as part of this project will continue to serve as a resource for investigating default-network subdivisions, associations of task-evoked responses with functional correlation profiles, and further innovations in optimizing data processing, analysis, and modeling. The vmPFC-optimized acquisition protocol and the network-based cortical parcellation methods developed as part of this project will provide tools to support future research on the cortical basis of higher-order cognition.
